stage.Label: Mama's Bar
stage.description: Mama's is a just-this-side-of-seedy bar and poetry slam joint in the university's student ghetto, where grad students, poets, Euro trash, and graffiti artists mingle with computer hackers and young MBAs who haven't let go of their college rebel image yet. Beer, heavy metal, and bad poetry flow freely. Don't talk to the poets; you'll only annoy them.

stage.Label: the clock tower
stage.description:
The clock tower perches atop the county courthouse. Its bell is no longer used; the belfry is sealed. History buffs know that the clock tower is the site of a local Romeo-and-Juliet style suicide pact, acted out back in '88, by the major 's son (white, Protestant, Ivy League, lineage traced to Mayflower) and the half-Pakistani, half-Cuban daughter of a small businessman (mixed-race, Muslim, recent immigrants). She became pregnant and they wanted to marry, but both sets of parents refused.
According to rumor, the mayor threatened to arrest the young man on trumped-up charges unless he left town immediately. Instead, the two young lovers climbed up to the belfy and during a local May Day celebration, as the mayor stepped up to the podium to speak, they hanged themselves from the bell's support beam, which caused the bell to begin ringing out of turn.
The bell has never been rung since.

stage.Label: the carnival
stage.description: Look! A German carnival is in town!

stage.Label: the river bank
stage.description: The river flows drowsily past this natural park, just outside the city limits. Paths meander along the river bank, and a warm breeze stirs in your hair. Dragonflies skim the water; silver glints below the surface as fish dart past. The crickets' chirp.

script.Notes: Do I really need the inner, nested "PastActorDescribed" clause?

Upstream, in Information: tell re inner trait, ThisSubject's evaluation of ThisActorDescribed's inner trait might have greatly diverged from the ReactingActor's, which would have resulted in ReactingActor losing a substantial amount of trust in ThisSubject. In this verb, if ThisSubject admits uncertainty in their evaluation of ThisActorDescribed's inner trait, ThisSubject will gain back some of the trust they lost.

This option is only available if the Subject contradicted you earlier, after you told them what you thought about a particular character's personality trait. (I set this in the TelleeContra:AssumeRoleIf script, up above. Note that the general Tellee role lacks this option.) This script looks hairy, but in concept, it is fairly simple. There are three elements to it. 1. The personality element: in general, how likely are you to scold someone? This element is a blend of two factors. First, how important to you, the Reacting Actor, is constructive social behavior (your P2Nasty_NiceWeight), and second, how willing are you to exert authority over another character to tell them if you think they are full of it (your P1Meek_Bossy)? 2. The inconsistency element: The particular reason for the scold. How different is what the Subject tells you now about another individual's personality traits, from what you told them before? In other words, this option comes at the end of a chain of events that started when you told them what you thought about a third party. They contradicted you, and at your urging, they have just told you what they think about that third party. Were they contradicting you because they really had a different opinion, or just to be argumentative? This clause helps you, the Reacting Actor figure that out. To know this, first you need to know how big a difference there is between their just-now-expressed opinion of the third party's inner trait, and your original opinion. To do this you take the BDifference of their Quantifier (i.e., their opinion of how nice, nasty, honest, bossy, chatty, etc., this other person is -- appears in the script as Quantifier2BNumber of ThisQuantifier) minus your original Quantifier (i.e., how nice, nasty, honest, chatty or whatever you said the third party was that caused the Subject to contradict you -- appears in the script as Quantifier2BNumber of PastQuantifier of LookUpCausalEvent of ..... several conditions that specify the correct quantifier). As usual, I take the absolute value of this BDifference (because it doesn't matter whose quantifier was higher or lower, only that there was a big difference between them), and use the poor woman's UNumber2BNumber, by subtracting that value from 0.5, so that this difference is in about the same range as the personality element (#1 above). The result is that the greater the difference in your opinion versus theirs, the less likely it is that they were being gratuitously contrary -- they truly have a substantively different opinion than yours about this third person. In other words, if you've just described Joan to Michael as being hugely nice, and Michael contradicted you and now tells you Joan is medium-huge nice, he's probably just being argumentative. Otoh, if he is now telling you that Joan is medium nasty, that's a substantive disagreement, so you might contradict him -- but you would unlikely to scold him for yanking your chain. 3. The third element is the usual loopy-booby escape hatch -- if you have scolded this person before, you are less likely to choose this option again.

Technically, I should have included a clause here specifying that two actors won't gossip about a third one if that third person is present... but in the interests of keeping the general purpose web simple from a learning standpoint, I have not. The same holds true for the other ask and tell verbs.

In this inclination, I want a character to base their decision to blow off an insult or social cut such as ignoring on whether it affects them strongly emotionally (a high Fearful or a high Angry), as well as whether or not they like (P2Nasty_Nice of Reacting Actor for This Subject) the person who is doing something hurtful. BDifference of 0.5 of AbsVal of Fearful_Angry is my rough and ready method for turning a quantity that behaves like a UNumber into a quantity that behaves more like a BNumber. Here is how it works. If a character is very fearful (Fearful_Angry of Reacting Actor is much less than 0.0) or very angry (Fearful_Angry of Reacting Actor is much greater than 0.0), I want them to be less inclined to choose this option than other options. This means I need to put their potential fearfulness on the same footing as their potential anger. I do this by taking the absolute value of their Fearful_Anger. Thus,if they are either very afraid or very angry, their BAbsVal (Fearful_Angry) will climb toward 1.0. Now I need to make them progressively =less= likely to choose never mind as their anger or fear goes up. I could do this by taking the additive inverse of this (BInverse). However, doing so would mean the influence of anger/fear on this option would push it toward a very infrequent choice. This is because BInverse (AbsVal (Fearful_Angry) would always max out at zero, while the factors in other inclination scripts can range all the way up to approaching 1.0. So instead, I subtract the mood severity expression BAbsVal (Fearful_Angry) from 0.5. (Full expression is BDifference of 0.5, BAbsVal of Fearful_Angry of Reacting Actor.) This causes the character's mood severity to range from 0.5 to approaching -1.0. Not perfect, but it should do for most situations. I blend this corrected mood severity expression with the character's P2Nasty_Nice of the subject, and then subtract the typical loopy-booby avoidance factor (the CountCausalEvents clause) from the result.
I use Sub_Dom weight as a representation of the reacting actor's ego. If someone compliments them, they are inclined to think well of that person.

For grins, I used the term defining how attractive the reacting actor thinks he or she is (P2Ugly_Attractive of ReactingActor). Basically, an actor who has low self confidence about his or her looks will have difficulty accepting a compliment.

For this adjust, I assume that if you like someone and they hug you, you like them more, but if you don't like them and they hug you, it makes you like them less. Also, I assume that ascetic people, who don't tend to seek out touch, have a stronger reaction to being hugged.

I want to apologize to my gay colleagues for the hetero-bias of some of these social interactions. To keep the general purpose web as simple as possible for teaching purposes, I had as a design criterion that I would not add custom traits and would keep the scripts as simple as possible. Not a good excuse for excluding people, I know. However, I can see some ways to achieve good results with a gay romance storyworld, and would be glad to discuss the matter with anyone who wants to give it a depart for.
I'm using the inverse of Cool_Volatile as a stand-in for whether someone would be likely to manipulate someone
I'm using the inverse of Cool_Volatile as a stand-in for whether someone would be likely to manipulate someone
